coredata.dc:title: Single local site structure for vibrationally distinct adsorption states: NO on Ni(111)
coredata.dc:creator: Asensio, M.C.
Woodruff, D.P.
Robinson, A.W.
Schindler, K.-M.
Gardner, P.
Ricken, D.
Bradshaw, A.M.
Conesa, J.C.
González-Elipe, A.R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Scanned energy mode N and O 1s photoelectron diffraction data collected from NO on Ni(111) under conditions corresponding to three distinct N—O vibrational frequencies, previously assigned to different (bridge and atop) local adsorption configurations, show that NO in all cases occupies the same site. Comparison of these data with the results of theoretical simulations indicates that the common site is a threefold coordinated hollow. These results indicate that there is a need to reevaluate the range of applicability of the widely used method of adsorption site assignment based on the numerical values of internal molecular vibrational frequencies.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 192, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I May 1992 Single local site structure for vibrationally distinct adsorption states: NO on Ni (111) M.C. Asensio', D.P. Woodruff Physics Department, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL, UK A.W. Robinson', K.-M. Schindler, P. Gardner, D. Ricken, A.M. Bradshaw Fritz-Haber-Institut, Faradayweg 4-6, W-1000 Berlin 33, Germany J.C. Conesa Instituto de Catalisis y Petroleoquimica, CSIC, Calle Serrano 119, 18006 Madrid, Spain and A.R. Gonz.Alez-Elipe Instituto de Ciencias de Materiales de Sevilla, CSIC, Apartacio 1115, 41071 Sevilla, Spain Received 30 January 1992; in final form 26 February 1992 Scanned energy mode N and O 1 s photoelectron diffraction data collected from NO on Ni (111) under conditions corresponding to three distinct N-O vibrational frequencies, previously assigned to different (bridge and atop) local adsorption configurations, show that NO in all cases occupies the same site. Comparison of these data with the results of theoretical simulations indicates that the common site is a threefold coordinated hollow. These results indicate that there is a need to reevaluate the range of applicability of the widely used method of adsorption site assignment based on the numerical values of internal molecular vibrational frequencies. 1. Introduction In studies of molecular adsorption at surfaces using vibrational spectroscopy both infrared reflection absorption spectroscopy (IRAs) and high resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS) have proved particularly successful because the spectroscopic resolution relative to the bandwidth range of information is high (particularly in IRAs). As a result these techniques are able to distinguish coexisting species in different adsorption states. In many cases, changes in internal molecular vibrational fre- Present address: Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales, Serrano 144, 28006 Madrid, Spain. Present address: Surface Science IRC, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 3BX, UK. 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. quencies have been assigned to different adsorbatesubstrate bonding geometries (e.g. atop, bridge) largely based on data from vibrational studies of inorganic cluster complexes of known structure. Rather few of these structural assignments in adsorption systems have been tested by detailed quantitative structural studies, although several CO adsorption structures (for which the cluster compounds are particularly well known) have been subjected to this test [ 1-3 ]. Here we show that a structural study of an NO adsorption system fails this test, which raises important questions concerning the general reliability of structural assignments of adsorbate systems based on vibrational spectroscopy. The specific system we have studied is NO adsorption on Nl(I I I). In this case IRAs experiments [4] (generally supported by HREELS of lower res- 259 Volume 192, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 May 1992 olution [ 5 ] ) indicate that essentially single species of quite distinct N-O vibrational frequencies are associated with low coverage NO, with a c (4 X 2) ordered structure assigned a coverage of 0.5 monolayers, and with NO coadsorbed with atomic oxygen [ 6 ] . These have been assigned to tilted and perpendicular bridge adsorbed NO, and atop adsorbed NO, respectively. Here we show evidence that these three different states actually correspond to the same local adsorbate geometry (which differs from all of these suggested structures). The method we use to investigate these structures is scanned energy mode photoelectron diffraction. This technique (e.g. refs. [7-11 ] ) involves the measurement of the intensity of core level photoemission from an atom within the adsorbate in a well-defined direction, as a function of photon, and thus photoelectron, energy. Coherent interference between components of the photoelectron wavefield directly emitted and elastically (back-) scattered by surrounding atoms leads to variations in the angle resolved photoemitted intensity which provide information on the scattering path lengths and thus the local bonding geometry. We have already demonstrated the utility of this method in the determination of molecular adsorbate structures for which the local environment of the different atomic species within the molecules can be probed independently [ 12-14 ] . 2. Experimental The experiments were conducted using synchrotron radiation from the BESSY storage ring in Berlin, dispersed by the Fritz Haber Institute's HE-TGM monochromator [ 15 ]. Photoelectron diffraction data were collected from both the O 1 s and N 1 s photoemission peaks at normal emission and at some off=normal emission angles over kinetic energy ranges of around 80-350 eV. The measurements were made at a fixed angle of incidence of 45 in the < 110 ) azimuth using a VG-Scientific ADES angle resolving electron spectrometer system. The Ni (111) sample was prepared by the usual combination of Laue Xray alignment, spark machining, mechanical polishing and in situ argon ion bombardment and annealing cycles until in situ LEED showed a clean surface (1 X 1) diffraction pattern, and X-ray 260 photoemission and NEXAFS indicated a clean surface. The NO exposures were performed at a sample temperature of approximately 90 K, and we concentrate here on three preparation conditions. Our reference state, obtained by exposures of typically 10 L, produced a sharp c (4 X 2) LEED pattern. A second phase associated with a coverage (assuming 0.5 ML for the c (4 X 2) phase) of approximately 0.1 ML, was formed by an exposure of the clean surface to 0.025 L. These two phases were prepared in order to correspond to the coverages in which vibrational spectroscopy [ 4 ] shows N-O stretching frequencies at 1585 and below 1500 cm-', respectively (and assigned on this basis to perpendicular and tilted bridging species). A third preparation involved initial exposure of the clean Ni (111) surface to 2.5 L oxygen at room temperature, producing a clear (,/3_X ,,/r3_) R30 structure in LEED measurements at low temperature, followed by a 2.5 L exposure of NO at 90 K. This preparation corresponds to that found to show N-O vibrational frequencies only above 1800 cm-' which have been assigned to atop adsorption [ 6 ] . 3. Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows a comparison of the normal emission N 1 s photoelectron diffraction spectra from these three different preparations and it is clear that the differences between them are extremely small, with all the main peaks remaining at the same energies and the only changes being in the relative amplitudes of features. As the NO molecule is known to bond to the surface through the N atom, the N 1 s spectra should be particularly sensitive to the local adsorbate-substrate bonding site, and previous studies using scanned energy mode photoelectron diffraction have demonstrated this site sensitivity for bonding at similar adsorbate-substrate bondlengths (as, for example, for O as chemisorbed O, in CH30 and in HCOO on Cu (100) [ 13,14,16,17 ] ) . On this basis we deduce from fig. 1, even in the absence of quantitative model calculations, that the adsorption sites of these three different states of NO are essentially the same; the small differences in the experimental spectra could be associated with differing adsorbate Volume 192, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 May 1992 N 1s Normal Emission a r : :low d ; ': ' y'~ coverage c :~ V 1 0 ~~ ~y f '.c(4x2) r ~ j ~'rwlr r .coads.0 100 200 300 400 Photoelectron Kinetic Energy (eV) Fig. 1. Comparison of the normal emission N 1 s scanned energy mode photoelectron diffraction spectra taken from NO adsorbed on Ni (111) in the low coverage, c (4 X 2 ) and oxygen coadsorption phases prepared as described in the text. scattering effects, or with small structural changes (such as local substrate atom relaxation) of no more than 0.05-0.1 A perpendicular to the surface or somewhat larger if parallel to the surface. We should also note that NEXAFS taken at both the N and O K edges confirms the essentially equivalent orientation of the NO molecules and indicates that in all cases the N-O axes are within 10 of the surface normal. This is in broad agreement with ESDIAD [ 18 ], photoemission [ 19 ] and Auger electron emission [ 20 ] data taken from the pure NO adsorption phases. We stress that this purely qualitative conclusion, that the adsorption site is identical in all three states, is based only on the comparison of the three experimental spectra of fig. 1 and the previously demonstrated sensitivity of such spectra to site changes [ 13,14,16,17 ] and is not reliant on any comparison of the experimental data with the results of theoretical calculations. The conclusion, however, is clearly at variance with the current interpretation of the vibrational spectroscopic data. Proper quantitative determination of the unique NO/Ni (111) structure for these three phases from the photoelectron diffraction data requires the use of model calculations. The general approach is similar to that used in LEED in that experimental intensityenergy spectra are compared with the results of sim- ulations of the scattering interferences which include a description of the scattering by individual atoms based on muffin-tin potentials, include the effect of inelastic scattering and thermal vibrations, and offer some provision for the effects of multiple scattering. These comparisons are conducted for a range of "guessed" structures until the agreement is sufficiently good, relative to the results for other models, to deem the structure to be solved. We have already shown that considerable success in this modelling can be achieved using double scattering approximate "curved wave" computations [ 11,13,14,17 ], and this is the approach we use here. We have made some comparisons between the results of this approximate method and those of calculations which use a more exact treatment of the curved wave, and find that the dominant structure is reproduced in both approaches; there are, however, small energy shifts between calculated spectra which could give rise to small ( < 0.1 A) systematic errors in bondlength assignment using the approximate method, and there are frequently differences in predicted fine structure. In considering the level of computational complexity required to model these experiments, we should note that higher order scattering is substantially less important in backscattering photoelectron diffraction than in LEED. One reason for this is the fact that a local, rather than remote (plane wave) source is used. Notice that in LEED the intensity oscillations in a fractional order diffracted beam energy spectrum for a simple overlayer adsorption structure (which are typically most sensitive to the adsorption site) result entirely from multiple scattering. By contrast, the primary interferences leading to these modulations in photoelectron diffraction energy spectra arise from single scattering. Typically, the main features of these data can therefore be reproduced by extremely simple single scattering calculations from very small clusters of atoms (i.e. 10 atoms or less, compared with the typically 500 atoms used in the calculations presented here). In the present case, the structural search concentrated on the reasonably symmetric atop, bridge and hollow sites, the last of these including sites directly above Ni atoms in the second substrate layer ("hcp" hollows) and those above Ni atoms in the third Ni layer ("fcc" hollows). We find it is possible to provide fits of the main features of the normal emission 261 Volume 192, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 May 1992 data of fig. 1 with both hollow and bridge sites at plausible, but different, N-Ni spacings (1.83 A for the fcc hollow but 1.75 A for the bridge site). This ambiguity might be perceived as undermining our earlier arguments that the lack of change of the normal emission spectra implies that there is no change of adsorption site. However, we should recognise that such a site change could only be reconciled with the normal emission spectra if it was accompanied by a change in the bondlength of just the amount needed to fit the photoelectron diffraction curves. In addition, we then require that the off normal emission data would have to be similarly insensitive to these combined site and bondlength changes, which as we show below, is certainly not the case. (We note that the experimental off-normal emission spectra show a similar weak dependence on the state of the layer (coverage, presence of coadsorbate) to the normal emission data in fig. 1.) It is worth noting that our inability to distinguish the fcc hollow and bridge sites on the basis of the normal emission data alone probably stems from the fact that neither of these sites places a near neighbour substrate scatterer directly behind the emitter relative to the detector at normal emission, so the geometry is not one which optimises the site sensitivity of the photoelectron diffraction method. Indeed, the absence of a single dominant scatterer may well also account for the failure of our calculations to reproduce the fine structure of the normal emission spectra with the level of success which we have achieved with earlier applications of the method. This discussion highlights the fact, however, that the site identification can be provided in a more convincing way by selecting off-normal emission geometries which do place a near neighbour substrate scatterer directly behind the emitter. When we do this we find that only the fcc site model is able to fit simultaneously both normal and off-normal emission spectra recorded from the N and O constituent atoms. Fig. 2 compares experimental data from the c (4 X 2 ) phase with the results of the calculations for the fcc and bridge site structures, in each case chosing the Ni-N distance which provides agreement with the normal emission data. The off-normal geometries used to collect the data of fig. 2 were chosen to place a nearest-neighbour Ni atom almost directly behind the emitter for fcc hollow site occupation, 262 0 E N 0 0 t a (a) bridge N 0 I ..-~..; ;r .~'O 0 v N 45 n , Y '4h: .J . O 29 100 200 300 100200 300 Photoelectron Kinetic Energy (eV) (b) f cc hollow N 0 N 45 w v~'\J ' O 29 Fig. 2. Comparison of the experimental N Is and O is scanned energy mode photo-electron diffraction spectra from Ni (111) c(4X2)-NO (shown as individual data points) with the results of theoretical calculations (smooth lines) for the best fit bridge (a) and "fcc" hollow (b) adsorption sites. The off-normal emission data were collected at polar angles (relative to the surface normal) and azimuthal angles (relative to a surface < 110) direction) of 45 and 33 (N Is) and 29 and 33 (O Is). leading to strong photoelectron diffraction modulations. By contrast, this collection geometry should lead to weak oscillations if the bridge site is occupied ( see theoretical curves in fig. 2, particularly for the N 1 s spectrum). Other off normal measurements recorded in a geometry which would optimise the oscillation amplitude for bridge site occupation led to very weak modulations experimentally, providing further confirmation of the hollow site assignment. We therefore conclude that NO occupies this hollow site, at least as the majority phase, in all three adsorption phases distinguished by their distinct N-O vibrational frequencies. This hollow site occupation has also been confirmed by an entirely independent SEXAFS determination [ 22 ] for the c ( 4 X 2 ) phase which actually leads to an implied N-Ni nearest neighbour distance of 1.82 A, in remarkable agreement with our own quantitative conclusions. In the light of these structural conclusions, we need to understand the origin of the major changes in vibrational frequencies in the hope that we can establish the extent to which internal molecular vibrational frequencies can, or cannot, be regarded as a Volume 192, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 May 1992 reliable guide to surface structure changes. The coadsorption state with oxygen is, perhaps, the easiest case for which a simple qualitative understanding of the N-O vibrational frequency can be achieved. Coadsorption of the strongly electronegative oxygen atoms may be expected to produce a significant change in the electronic environment of the adsorbed NO species, and the direction of the change to a stiffer N-O bond is consistent with electron donation from the partially occupied antibonding 2n orbital of NO. The N-O bond strength is more readily changed in NO than in CO in which the 2n level of the free molecule is unoccupied, and even in CO considerable C-O bond weakening is known to occur in coadsorption with electron donating alkali metal atoms [ 21 ] . Notice that in the coadsorption phase the presence of two oxygen species precludes the use of photoelectron diffraction in our experiments to determine the O site in the NO, so we are unable to investigate the change in N-O bondlength which might be expected to accompany a change in occupation of the antibonding orbital. In the case of NO adsorption on the clean surface, the smaller vibrational frequency shift observed between the low and high coverage phases (x 80 cm-') is unlikely to be accompanied by an N-O bondlength change of more than a few hundredths of an Angstr6m unit, which falls within the range of uncertainty of our method. For the low and high coverage phases of NO alone, vibrational spectroscopy shows N-O stretching bands in two regions (around 1460-1510 cm-' and 15501585 cm-' ), with the low energy band growing first at low coverage and intensity gradually transferring to the higher energy band at high coverages so that at the nominal half-monolayer of the c (4 X 2) phase only the high energy band is seen. There is also some trend for each band to move up in frequency as the coverage increases, as to be expected from dipole-dipole interactions in the overlayer. This behaviour is certainly most easily explained by the occupation of two different sites (or at least two distinct surface species such as the perpendicular and tilted molecules which have been proposed). An alternative explanation, however, emerges from our conclusion that the NO always occupies one specific (fcc) hollow site. In the past, the c (4 X 2) surface mesh has always been accounted for by adsorbing NO molecules into symmetrically inequivalent bridge sites, such that the NO molecules lie on a primitive submesh, but the two inequivalent bridge sites lead to two NO molecules for each primitive mesh of the coincidence c (4 X 2 ) structure (see fig. 3a). The NO molecules in this structure are thus equispaced at a separation of 3.29 A. If the c (4 X 2) phase comprises a half-monolayer of NO molecules all in identical fcc hollows, however, these st form zig-zag chains on the surface with a substantially shorter NO-NO nearest neighbour distance of 2.49 A (fig. 3b). Note that a mixture of fcc and hcp hollow sites (fig. 3c) would relax this intermolecular spacing to 2.88 A, but the photoelectron diffraction data are inconsistent with this structure. An important consequence of fcc hollow site occupation is that beyond a coverage of 0.25 mono- A Fig. 3. Schematic diagram of possible arrangements of 0.5 ML of NO molecules ( small filled circles) to form a c ( 4 X 2 ) overlayer structure on Ni(111), the top layer atoms of which are represented by open circles. (A) shows the usual model based on inequivalent bridge sites, (B) is the structure proposed in which equivalent (fcc) hollow sites are occupied, whilst (C) shows a structure based on inequivalent (fcc and hcp) hollow sites. The full and dashed lines show the c ( 4 X 2 ) and primitive surface unit nets. 263 Volume 192, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 May 1992 layers, short NO-NO distance first occur until, at 0.5 References monolayers, all NO molecules have these nearest neighbours. This sharp change in the NO-NO near est-neighbour distance is expected to lead to a sharp increase in the N-O vibrational frequency due to di pole-dipole interactions (e.g. ref. [23] ), and there fore provides an alternative explanation for the two main vibrational bands seen in the NO /Ni(11 I ) ad sorption system. In some senses this explanation of the frequency shifts is similar to an earlier proposal involving the formation of NO dimers on the surface [ 24 ] ; it is not clear, however, whether the NO-NO interactions in these nearest neighbour sites are at tractive (as implied by dimerisation) or repulsive (as in many CO adsorption systems [ 25 ] ) . Note that photoelectron diffraction would not be very sensi tive to small (0.1-0.2 A) displacements parallel to the surface from the hollow site which might accom pany strong intermolecular forces. In summary, we have shown that for the case of NO adsorbed on Ni (111) at various coverages and coadsorbed with oxygen, the NO molecules always occupy the same hollow adsorption sites, and have proposed that the marked changes in N-O vibra tional frequencies previously assigned to different adsorption sites can all be accounted for in terms of local changes in electronic structure or vibrational coupling. Clearly these results highlight the need for great caution in making structural assignments on the basis only of the numerical values of internal vi brational frequencies of adsorbed molecules. We should note, however, that the case of NO adsorp tion is very different from the far more extensively studied case of CO for which there are excellent ref erence spectra from cluster compounds, and for which the absence of any occupation of the 2n an tibonding state in the free molecule means that changes to the intramolecular bond strength may be less easily effected. Note that photoelectron diffraction would not be very sensi tive to small (0.1-0.2 A) displacements parallel to the surface from the hollow site which might accom pany strong intermolecular forces. In summary, we have shown that for the case of NO adsorbed on Ni (111) at various coverages and coadsorbed with oxygen, the NO molecules always occupy the same hollow adsorption sites, and have proposed that the marked changes in N-O vibra tional frequencies previously assigned to different adsorption sites can all be accounted for in terms of local changes in electronic structure or vibrational coupling. head.ce:title: Single local site structure for vibrationally distinct adsorption states: NO on Ni(111)

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Scanned energy mode N and O 1s photoelectron diffraction data collected from NO on Ni(111) under conditions corresponding to three distinct N—O vibrational frequencies, previously assigned to different (bridge and atop) local adsorption configurations, show that NO in all cases occupies the same site. Comparison of these data with the results of theoretical simulations indicates that the common site is a threefold coordinated hollow. These results indicate that there is a need to reevaluate the range of applicability of the widely used method of adsorption site assignment based on the numerical values of internal molecular vibrational frequencies.

sb:reference.sb:comment: Suppl. Le Vide, les Couches Minces No. 201
